nodes.title: "It was such a hard right-wing, racist society that I grew up in. I have a lot of friends and even kinfolk who never tried to move beyond the racism. But I try every day. Itâ€™s been an ongoing, gradual transformation," the writer John Grisham tells @NYTmag. https://t.co/qMJK6iMZCr

nodes.title: Britain declared a national incident after finding evidence suggesting local spread of poliovirus in London. No cases of polio have been identified so far, but officials urged those who were not fully immunized to seek vaccines immediately. https://t.co/BwaLh50ja4

nodes.title: Rupert Murdoch and Jerry Hall are said to be getting divorced. Murdochâ€™s fourth divorce is unlikely to change the ownership structure of his empire, but it could reverberate through companies such as Fox News and The Wall Street Journal. https://t.co/cz2tXZseU2

nodes.title: Who stops a "bad guy with a gun?" It's usually not law enforcement. A review of 433 shootings in the U.S. shows that most are over by the time the police arrive. Bystanders sometimes stop attackers, but seldom shoot them. https://t.co/mhNvTuCEa9 https://t.co/LhUMBZxdB5

nodes.title:
In Opinion

"With each hearing, it becomes clearer that Trump has no plausible deniability," writes @maureendowd. "He put the lives of the vice president and his family at risk, as well as the lives of lawmakers." https://t.co/JalUbcrR9r
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: President Biden fell off his bike on Saturday while trying to dismount in front of a small crowd of reporters and onlookers. He did not appear to suffer any injuries, and the White House said he did not require medical attention. https://t.co/r6VtApkdVu
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title:
Cryptocurrency prices are plummeting and investors have been plunged into financial ruin.

Now, concern is mounting over another potential vulnerability in the market: Tether, a company whose namesake currency is a linchpin of crypto trading worldwide. https://t.co/xA6S0R72s7
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Breaking News: CDC advisers unanimously recommended Covid vaccines for children under 5, the last group of Americans to qualify for the shots. If the agencyâ€™s director endorses the move, immunizations could start Tuesday. https://t.co/byCDIEE0ZY
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: If the Justice Department brings a case against Donald Trump, prosecutors face the challenge of showing he knew â€” or should have known â€” that assertions about election fraud were false, or that his attempt to block congressional certification was illegal. https://t.co/e02Y9nnCZv
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title:
The European Commission recommended on Friday that Ukraine be granted candidate status in the countryâ€™s bid to become a member of the EU.
It also recommended a similar status for Moldova, but it declined to recommend candidacy for neighboring Georgia. https://t.co/urFFq589Z1 https://t.co/I6lnZrZJRK
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Breaking news: Bitcoin plummeted below $20,000 for the first time since November 2020, driven partly by the recent collapse of two big cryptocurrency projects. https://t.co/IBiEUDgFUo
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Gun companies are refocusing their message away from hunting and toward personal safety, including the sale of military-style weapons attractive to mostly young men. Their pitch â€” rooted in self-defense, machismo and fear â€” has been remarkably successful. https://t.co/Nf8KlJQgdz https://t.co/zO2BtRnaeh
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: President Volodymyr Zelensky made an unannounced visit Saturday to Mykolaiv, a Ukrainian city battered by the war that has been held up by Kyiv as a sign of fierce resistance. He visited a hospital and said the staff who saved lives were "heroic people." https://t.co/jkiQ5eFKdf https://t.co/heSBHsaMMj
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title:
In Opinion

"While the committee is rightly seeking testimony from Ginni Thomas, Democrats should say something too. They shouldnâ€™t just say something, they should scream something," writes Jamelle Bouie. https://t.co/n1pVncENRK
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Mark Shields, a fixture in American political journalism and punditry who was seen on "PBS NewsHour" for 33 years, died on Saturday at his home in Maryland. He was 85. https://t.co/9xvRiAGTiv https://t.co/6dGGMSEOPX
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: "Plan 75," the new film from Japanese director Chie Hayakawa, has a shocking premise about a government push to euthanize the elderly. It takes on one of Japan's biggest elephants in the room: the challenges of dealing with the worldâ€™s oldest society. https://t.co/u10PiJAJsm https://t.co/fhzTMuI6ip
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: In a nation at war, and a city aching for some semblance of normality, the Odesa Opera reopened on Friday for the first time since the Russian invasion began. The performance began with an impassioned rendering of the Ukrainian national anthem. https://t.co/kaiMsj4FrD https://t.co/kP9AddELQI
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: U.S. Capitol Police arrested a production team for "The Late Show With Stephen Colbert" who were filming a segment that featured Triumph the Insult Comic Dog, and charged them with unlawful entry. https://t.co/OiGBzbhKkT
